description: From Middle English waveren, from Old Norse vafra (“to flicker”), akin to Old English wǣfre (“restless, wavering”). Related to wave.

entries.meaning: An act of wavering, vacillating, etc.
Someone who waves, enjoys waving, etc.
examples: I felt encouraged by all the enthusiastic wavers in the crowd.
The Fourth of July brings out all the flag wavers.
Johnny is such a little waver; everyone who passes by receives his preferred greeting.

entries.meaning: Someone who specializes in waving (hair treatment).
A tool that accomplishes hair waving.
(UK, dialect, dated) A sapling left standing in a fallen wood.

verbs.description: waver (third-person singular simple present wavers, present participle wavering, simple past and past participle wavered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To sway back and forth; to totter or reel.
(intransitive) To flicker, glimmer, quiver, as a weak light.
(intransitive) To fluctuate or vary, as commodity prices or a poorly sustained musical pitch.
(intransitive) To shake or tremble, as the hands or voice.
examples: His voice wavered when the reporter brought up the controversial topic.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To falter; become unsteady; begin to fail or give way.
examples: Although they believe they can overhaul their 2-0 deficit, they cannot afford to be as lethargic as this at Camp Nou, and the time is surely approaching when Manuel Pellegrini's faith in Martín Demichelis wavers.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be indecisive between choices; to feel or show doubt or indecision; to vacillate.
examples: Despite all the terrible things that happened to her, she never wavered from her beliefs.
